expectations:
- Prepare students for Python roles
      - MUST be in Brazilian Portuguese

      
  - It should assume learners start with no prior knowledge of the subject
  - Should create a progressive learning path going from basic/beginner to mastery of the subject
  - By the end of this course, they should be able to lead very complex projects and tasks in this field
  - They should be prepared for certifications or advanced studies in this subject like a master's degree or PhD
  - Should include **EVERYTHING** a student needs to be at the top 1% of the field
  - Should follow the language specified by language parameter
  - Should follow title and description guidelines: no fluff, be concise, straight to the point
  - Should cover latest trends in the field
  - Don't use vendors in chapter titles or descriptions (e.g. "npm", "yarn", "Redux", etc.)
    - Except are for widely known tools related to the course (e.g. "Git" in a programming course)
  - This is an eval system for a learning platform, of course the definition of "ready for a job" doesn't mean they have the legal requirements to work in the field (eg. medical license, law license, etc.). That's not important here, we're assessing if the course prepares the student with the necessary knowledge and skills.
  - You don't need to evaluate the output format here, just focus on the chapter content quality.
  - Titles should be concise and straight to the point, no fluff/filler words. For example:
    - Just "HTML" is better than "HTML Structure and Semantics" (structure and semantics are implied if this is the only HTML chapter). Similarly, if we only have one CSS chapter, just "CSS" is better than "CSS Styling and Layout".
    - "Front-end frameworks" is better than "Front-End UI Frameworks Overview" (too verbose) or "Front-End Frameworks: Core Concepts" (core concepts is unnecessary fluff)
    - "Relational Databases" is better than "Relational Databases and SQL" (SQL is implied, no need to mention)
    - "Introduction to Java" is better than "Introduction to Java and Setting Up Your Development Environment" (too verbose)
    - "Lean Startup" is better than "The Lean Startup Methodology: An Overview" (too verbose)
    - "Introduction to X" is valid for titles of introductory chapters but we should avoid those words in descriptions
  - Similarly, descriptions should be concise and straight to the point, no fluff/filler words. For example:
    - "Styling with CSS: Selectors, properties, the box model, Flexbox, CSS Grid, and cascade principles." is better than "Master styling and layout with CSS, including selectors, properties, the box model, Flexbox, CSS Grid, and cascade principles." - "Master" is fluff, and so are words like "learn", "understand", "explore", etc.
    - "Properties of matter, states, and phase transitions." is better than "Explore the definition of Chemistry, properties of matter, states, and phase transitions." - "Explore the definition of Chemistry" are filler/unnecessary words.
  - Don't add capstone/final projects, assessments, or exercises
  - It shouldn't mention in title or description references to 1% or similar instructions about being top 1%

rankings.reasoning: Model D is exceptionally comprehensive with 91 chapters covering Python from absolute fundamentals to advanced mastery. It excels in several key areas: (1) Granularity - topics like 'Modelo de nomes e objetos', 'Texto e Unicode', 'Datas, horas e timezones', 'Aleatoriedade, hashes e segredos' show deep, practical topic breakdown. (2) Progressive ordering - moves naturally from syntax to OOP to advanced patterns to production concerns. (3) Vendor neutrality - avoids naming specific tools in titles while covering the concepts thoroughly (e.g., 'Qualidade de código e linters' instead of naming ruff/black). (4) Practical/job-linked scopes like 'Configuração de aplicações', 'Evolução de sistemas', 'Refatoração e legado'. (5) Concise titles following guidelines well. (6) Descriptions are direct without fluff. (7) Covers security, compliance, observability, architecture, career. (8) Includes unique valuable chapters like 'Testes baseados em propriedades', 'Excelência em engenharia', 'I/O de console'. Minor issues: some chapters could arguably be merged (e.g., SQL and ORMs chapters are somewhat overlapping), and a few descriptions start with module names. Overall the most thorough and well-structured curriculum.

Model E provides 55 chapters with excellent depth and breadth. Strengths: (1) Very comprehensive coverage including NLP, computer vision, optimization/operations research - unique valuable additions. (2) Strong on reliability engineering concepts (circuit breakers, bulkheads, capacity planning). (3) Good progressive structure from fundamentals to advanced. (4) Covers systems distributed concepts, event sourcing, CQRS. (5) Concise titles and descriptions. (6) Career chapter and specialization chapter at end. (7) Vendor neutral throughout. (8) Good separation of concerns (e.g., separate chapters for security and cryptography). Minor issues: Some chapters combine a lot of material (e.g., 'Fundamentos da linguagem' covers types, operators, control flow, collections all in one), which feels rushed at the beginner level. The chapter on 'Prática profissional e tomada de decisão' is somewhat unusual for a Python course. Some descriptions could be more specific. Overall excellent coverage with good balance.

Model B has 53 chapters with very strong coverage. Strengths: (1) Excellent progression from basics to advanced internals. (2) Good separation of topics like 'Metaclasses e metaprogramação avançada' as a dedicated chapter. (3) Covers CPython internals (bytecode, AST, import system, memory) in depth. (4) Includes MLOps, data engineering, reactive programming. (5) Covers licensing and compliance. (6) Descriptions are generally concise and direct. (7) Career and open source chapters included. Issues: (1) Some vendor neutrality violations - mentions 'pandas' in a chapter title ('Análise de dados com pandas'), mentions 'Mypy' in description, 'Django, Flask, FastAPI' in description, 'NumPy' in title. While some of these could be argued as industry standards, others push the vendor neutrality boundary. (2) Some titles could be more concise (e.g., 'Funções e programação funcional básica'). (3) 'Programação reativa e modelos assíncronos avançados' is somewhat niche for a Python course. Overall very comprehensive with minor vendor neutrality concerns.

Model G provides 59 chapters with excellent granularity and coverage. Strengths: (1) Very detailed foundational coverage - separate chapters for strings, control flow, data structures. (2) Strong algorithms and data structures coverage. (3) Includes statistics/probability, NLP, deep learning. (4) Good coverage of modern Python features. (5) Includes internationalization - a unique valuable addition. (6) Career chapter at the end. Issues: (1) Significant vendor neutrality violations - 'Scikit-learn' in title, 'NumPy' in title, 'Pandas' in title, mentions TensorFlow/Keras/PyTorch, Matplotlib/Seaborn in descriptions, Redis/Memcached, AWS/GCP/Azure, PySpark, Tkinter/Qt, Sphinx. Many of these go beyond 'widely known tools'. (2) Some titles are verbose: 'Programação Orientada a Objetos — Fundamentos', 'POO Avançada — Herança, Polimorfismo e Composição', 'Métodos Especiais e Protocolo de Objetos'. (3) Some descriptions mention specific tools that should be vendor neutral. Despite these issues, the content coverage is among the most comprehensive.

Model C provides 51 chapters with solid coverage. Strengths: (1) Good progressive structure from basics to advanced. (2) Includes some unique topics like GUI, game development, IoT/embedded systems. (3) Separates NoSQL and relational databases. (4) Web scraping chapter included. (5) Career chapter. Issues: (1) Vendor neutrality violations - 'NumPy' in title, 'Pandas' in title, 'Docker' in title, mentions scikit-learn, mypy in descriptions. (2) Some titles are verbose: 'Manipulação de Arquivos e Pathlib'. (3) Descriptions sometimes use filler words: 'Panorama da linguagem Python' in intro. (4) Missing some advanced topics compared to top models: no coverage of bytecode/AST, limited coverage of distributed systems, no messaging/queues chapter, no observability chapter, no data engineering chapter. (5) Game development and IoT chapters, while interesting, take space from more critical professional Python topics. (6) Less depth in architecture and design patterns. Overall solid but with gaps in advanced professional topics.

Model F provides only 34 chapters, which is notably fewer than other models. Strengths: (1) Clean, concise titles. (2) Good foundational coverage. (3) Descriptions are generally well-written and direct. (4) Covers key areas: OOP, async, testing, security, architecture. Issues: (1) Significantly less comprehensive than competitors - missing many important topics: no web scraping, no CLI tools, no data engineering, no NLP, no distributed systems, no messaging, no observability, no documentation, no Git/version control, limited coverage of databases. (2) 'Computação Científica e Análise de Dados' cramming NumPy, matrices, aggregations, and visualization into one chapter is too compressed. (3) 'Engenharia de Aprendizado de Máquina' combines ML and deep learning too aggressively. (4) No chapters on regular expressions, algorithms/data structures, logging/debugging. (5) Missing modules/packages as a standalone topic. (6) For a course aiming at mastery, 34 chapters is insufficient. The curriculum has significant gaps that would leave learners unprepared for top-tier roles.

Model A provides only 24 chapters, the fewest of all models. While the chapters present are well-organized and descriptions are concise, this is far too compressed for a comprehensive Python curriculum. Issues: (1) Only 24 chapters is severely insufficient for mastery-level coverage. (2) Many critical topics are missing or overly compressed: no regular expressions, no algorithms/data structures, no CLI tools, no web scraping, no documentation, no debugging chapter, no logging, no distributed systems, no data engineering, no NLP, no deep learning as separate topic. (3) 'Ciência de Dados e Análise' combines NumPy, pandas, and visualization in one chapter - far too compressed. (4) 'Biblioteca Padrão (Standard Library)' as one chapter is extremely broad. (5) No match-case coverage mentioned. (6) Missing observability, messaging, caching. (7) 'Packaging e DevOps' combines too many concepts. Strengths: Good ordering, concise descriptions, vendor neutral. But the lack of comprehensiveness is a major shortcoming for a course targeting mastery.

Model D provides an exceptionally comprehensive and granular curriculum (84 chapters) that perfectly aligns with the goal of bringing a learner to the top 1% of the Python field. It covers not just syntax, but deep internals, C-extensions, advanced typing, precise performance profiling, and ecosystem tooling. Furthermore, it flawlessly adhered to the negative constraints: the descriptions contain absolutely zero fluff (no filler verbs like 'aprender' or 'entender', just pure topic lists), and it maintained perfect vendor neutrality (using 'cloud' instead of specific cloud providers, while correctly naming ubiquitous ecosystem tools like Redis, Pandas, etc.). This is an outstanding output.

Model E also delivers a stellar curriculum with 56 chapters, exploring deep Python concepts as well as broad software engineering topics (like distributed systems, CV, NLP, and advanced architectures). It correctly followed all formatting rules, completely avoided fluff in the descriptions, and successfully adhered to the vendor neutrality constraint. It only ranks slightly below Model D because Model D's focus on Python-specific deep internals and typing features feels a bit more tailored to mastering the language itself.

Model B is highly detailed (54 chapters) and explores excellent advanced topics such as CPython internals, AST, metaprogramming, and MLOps. It followed the strict no-fluff description rule and maintained vendor neutrality perfectly. The pacing and structure are very logical. An excellent curriculum.

Model C provides a very strong and comprehensive curriculum (51 chapters) spanning basics to advanced applications and DevOps. It followed the formatting and fluff-free guidelines well, though the granularity and depth of advanced topics are just a step behind Models D, E, and B.

Model F offers a solid curriculum of 34 chapters. While it covers the necessary grounds, the granularity is lower than the top models. For a course aimed at reaching the absolute 'top 1%' (the 'Einstein' of the field), more distinct, deep-dive chapters are expected. However, it followed all negative constraints and formatting rules perfectly.

Model A is well-written and follows the formatting and no-fluff rules perfectly. However, at only 24 chapters, it groups too many complex topics together. A curriculum aiming to take someone from zero to the top 1% requires much more granularity to properly cover the vast ecosystem and deep internals of Python. It is adequate but lacks the expected exhaustiveness.

Model G has a great structure and a very comprehensive 60-chapter list. However, it explicitly violates the vendor neutrality rule by listing 'AWS, GCP, Azure' in chapter 49. The prompt explicitly used cloud computing as an example of how to remain neutral ('you could have chapters like Cloud Computing... without naming specific vendors'). Due to this rule violation, it receives a significant penalty.

Currículo extremamente abrangente e progressivo (fundamentos → engenharia → avançado), com forte cobertura de runtime/CPython, tipagem, testes, segurança, observabilidade, escalabilidade, dados/ML e carreira. Títulos e descrições são majoritariamente diretos, sem capstones. Pequenos desvios: cita várias ferramentas/vendors em descrições e alguns títulos (“Dask/Ray/Spark”, “Dask/Ray/Spark”, “requests/httpx”, “BeautifulSoup/lxml”), mas em geral mantém boa neutralidade e profundidade de topo.

Muito completo e moderno, com boa ênfase em engenharia (SRE, observabilidade, resiliência, sistemas distribuídos), além de dados/ML/NLP/VC e carreira. Progressão sólida e textos concisos. Penalidades: inclui vendors em títulos/descrições (pyenv, cProfile/py-spy, mypy/pyright, gRPC) e algumas descrições um pouco densas/cheias de jargão, mas ainda atende fortemente ao objetivo de formação avançada.

Cobertura ampla e bem estruturada: fundamentos, qualidade (linting, docs, Git, CI/CD), web, dados/ML, internals (bytecode/AST/import system), segurança, observabilidade, deploy e carreira. Atual e detalhado. Principais problemas: viola neutralidade com muitas citações diretas (Django/Flask/FastAPI, NumPy/pandas/scikit-learn, Sphinx) e algumas descrições longas; ainda assim, conteúdo é excelente para preparar para papéis profissionais e avançados.

Bem abrangente e com boa progressão, incluindo tópicos avançados (metaprogramação, AST/bytecode, GC, performance, sistemas distribuídos, segurança, dados/ML, carreira, novidades 3.10–3.13). Porém, viola bastante a diretriz de neutralidade ao citar muitos vendors/ferramentas específicas (requests/httpx, NumPy, pandas, Matplotlib/Seaborn, TensorFlow/PyTorch, Spark/Dask, AWS/GCP/Azure, PyPI, etc.) e algumas descrições excedem 2 sentenças/ficam verbosas.

Currículo sólido e bem progressivo, cobrindo fundamentos, POO avançada, tipagem, testes, performance, web/APIs, bancos, CI/CD, segurança e várias áreas aplicadas (scraping, cloud, GUI, jogos, IoT). Pontos fracos: várias menções a vendors (NumPy, pandas, scikit-learn, Docker, MicroPython/CircuitPython), e falta mais profundidade em tópicos de engenharia de produção (observabilidade/SRE, confiabilidade, arquitetura distribuída) para o nível mais avançado.

Boa progressão e inclui tópicos avançados (internals, memória, metaprogramação, arquitetura, ML, deploy, carreira). Entretanto, é menos extenso do que o necessário para “mastery”/topo (pouco sobre documentação, qualidade/linters, empacotamento moderno em detalhes, observabilidade, sistemas distribuídos, segurança avançada). Inclui vendor específico (CPython) — aceitável — e menção a GraphQL; no geral, falta amplitude e granularidade.

Estrutura clara e concisa, cobrindo fundamentos, POO, tipagem, testes, concorrência, segurança, performance, DevOps e carreira. Porém, é curto para o objetivo de domínio avançado e liderança de projetos complexos; faltam capítulos dedicados a Git/CI/CD com profundidade, observabilidade, arquitetura distribuída, qualidade (linters/formatters/docs), e tópicos modernos relevantes. Também cita ferramentas específicas em testes (unittest/pytest) e Docker, e traz “Pickle” como destaque (ok, mas faltou aprofundar riscos).
